content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Claudia Schultz: I was born in Chicago, but I grew up in Evanston, which is just a few miles away. My parents were both highly educated—my father had a graduate degree in engineering, and my mother earned a bachelor's in education. We lived in a comfortable home, and while my mother didn't work outside the home during my childhood, she was always involved in community activities and volunteering. I was raised Catholic, but as I got older, I became more secular in my views. I went to a good public school system, which gave me a strong academic foundation. I was always interested in learning, and I ended up pursuing a graduate degree in public policy, which I completed a few years ago. After that, I took a break from full-time work to focus on family, but I've been working part-time as a consultant in urban planning ever since. Life has had its ups and downs, but I've always tried to stay grounded and focused on what matters most.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Claudia Schultz: Yes, there was a defining moment that shaped the course of my life. I was in my second year of college, studying political science, when I had the opportunity to intern with a local nonprofit focused on urban development. At the time, I was on a path to become a lawyer, but this experience opened my eyes to the power of policy in creating real change in people's lives. I remember one particular project where we worked to revitalize a neighborhood that had been neglected for years. I saw how policy decisions could either uplift or abandon communities, and it made me realize that I wanted to be part of the solution, not just the system. That internship was the crossroads—after that, I switched my focus to public policy, earned my graduate degree, and eventually found my way into urban planning. It was a difficult decision at the time, because I had invested so much in the legal field, but looking back, it was the right choice for who I wanted to be.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Claudia Schultz: I think it was a conscious choice, but one that felt inevitable after that internship. I had been questioning whether law was the right path for me, but I didn't fully realize it until I saw the impact of policy work firsthand. It wasn't just about changing my major—it was about redefining my purpose. I remember sitting in my dorm room that night, staring at my law textbooks, and thinking, 'This isn't where I'm meant to be.' I made a list of all the things that mattered to me: community, equity, and the ability to create tangible change. Public policy checked all those boxes. So, I made the decision to pivot, even though it felt risky. I had to take out loans for my graduate degree, and there were moments of doubt, but I believed in the path I chose. Looking back, I don't think I could have made a different decision and still been true to myself.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Claudia Schultz: Absolutely, I think having someone who could offer guidance or a different perspective would have made a difference. My mother, for instance, was always supportive, but she never had the same kind of career path I was considering. However, I was lucky to have a professor in my political science department who had worked in urban planning. She took me under her wing after that internship and encouraged me to explore that field more deeply. She even helped me connect with people in the industry and gave me the confidence to make the switch. I also remember talking to a few friends who were in similar situations, and hearing their stories helped me realize I wasn't alone in feeling uncertain. So, while the decision was ultimately mine, I don't think I would have made it as smoothly without the support and encouragement of those around me.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Claudia Schultz: I'm married to a man named Daniel, who works as a software developer for a small tech startup in Chicago. We met in graduate school, actually—though he was studying computer science and I was in public policy, we had a few classes together and bonded over our shared interest in how technology can shape communities. We've been married for about seven years now, and we have a five-year-old daughter named Lily. She's a curious and energetic child, and I love seeing the world through her eyes. Daniel and I have a good balance in our lives—he handles the more technical aspects of our household, while I focus on our daughter's education and our community involvement. We both work part-time, which allows us to be more present for Lily, though it's not always easy. We live in a cozy home in Evanston, just a few blocks from where I grew up, which feels like a nice connection to my roots.

Going through the interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by key moments and the people around me. Starting from my childhood in Evanston, where I was raised in a supportive and intellectually stimulating environment, to the pivotal internship that shifted my career path from law to public policy, each step has led me to where I am today. It wasn't just about making a decision—it was about aligning my values with my work, and I'm grateful for the guidance I received along the way. Now, as a mother and a part-time urban planner, I feel a deep sense of purpose, knowing that I'm contributing to my community in a way that matters to me. The interview process helped me see how interconnected my past experiences, relationships, and choices have been in defining who I am now.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Claudia Schultz: My immediate family includes my parents, who still live in Evanston. My father, Thomas, is retired now but was a professor of engineering at a local university before he retired. He's always been a big supporter of my career choices, even when I took the less traditional path of switching from law to public policy. My mother, Margaret, is still very active in the community—she volunteers at a local food bank and is on the board of a nonprofit that supports education for underprivileged children. Our relationship is close, though we don't see each other as often as I'd like. I still visit them regularly, and they always have open arms and a warm meal waiting for me. I also have an older brother, Michael, who lives in San Francisco and works in finance. We don't talk as much as I'd like, but when we do, it's always a reminder of how different our paths have been. He's always been more of a traditionalist, and while I respect his choices, I think our conversations often highlight how much my values have shaped my life in ways that differ from his. Still, I'm grateful for our family, and I know I wouldn't be where I am today without their support and influence.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Claudia Schultz: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been incredibly important to me. One of them is Sarah, a fellow urban planner who I met during my graduate studies. We've been close ever since, and she's been a great mentor and sounding board for me throughout my career. We often collaborate on community projects, and I value her perspective because she's always pushing me to think more creatively about how we can make cities more inclusive and sustainable. Then there's my friend James, who works in social work. He's been a constant presence in my life, and our conversations often circle back to the intersection of policy and social justice. He's helped me stay grounded in the real-world impact of my work, which is something I really appreciate. I also have a small group of friends from college who I keep in touch with, even if we don't see each other as often as we'd like. They've been there for me through the ups and downs of life, and I'm grateful for their friendship. In many ways, these relationships have been just as formative as my family in shaping who I am today.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Claudia Schultz: I live in a neighborhood that feels like a mix of old and new—Evanston has this charm where historic homes sit alongside modern apartments and coffee shops. My street, Lakeview Drive, is quiet in the mornings, with the sound of birds and the occasional jogger passing by. There's a community garden just a few blocks away that I like to visit on weekends, and it's become a gathering spot for neighbors to share ideas and grow food together. The area is walkable, which is something I really appreciate, especially with Lily around. We're close to parks, libraries, and a few local businesses that support independent artisans. I also love that there's a strong sense of community here—people know each other, and there's always someone willing to lend a hand. It's not perfect, of course, like any place, but I feel like I'm part of something bigger here, which aligns with my values as an urban planner. I want to help shape spaces that foster connection and inclusivity, and living in this neighborhood reminds me every day why that work matters.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Claudia Schultz: I feel very safe in my neighborhood, which is something I really appreciate. There's a sense of familiarity and trust among the residents here. I've never felt threatened or uncomfortable walking around, even late at night. The local police department has a good relationship with the community, and there are neighborhood watch programs that keep things peaceful. I also think the diversity of people here contributes to that safety—there's a shared commitment to looking out for one another. It's not just about avoiding danger; it's about feeling like you belong and that your well-being is valued. That sense of security is something I try to bring into my work as an urban planner, because I believe that safe, inclusive spaces are the foundation of any thriving community.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Claudia Schultz: Living here has been mostly positive, but like anywhere, there are challenges. One of the things I appreciate most is the walkability and the sense of community I mentioned earlier. However, there are also moments when I feel the weight of the city's ongoing issues—like housing affordability and the pressure of development that sometimes prioritizes profit over people. I've seen some of the neighborhoods I work with struggle with displacement, and it's heartbreaking to see long-time residents forced out. That's why my work as an urban planner is so important to me—it's not just about designing spaces, but about ensuring that everyone has a place to belong. At the same time, living in Evanston has given me a deep appreciation for the small things: the local bookstores, the farmers' markets, the way the seasons change here. It's a place that feels like home, even with its imperfections, and I'm grateful for that.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how deeply connected my personal life is to the work I do as an urban planner. Talking about my husband Daniel, our daughter Lily, and my parents reminded me of the importance of community and the values that shape my decisions. It also made me think about how the neighborhood I live in—Evanston—has influenced my perspective on what makes a place safe, inclusive, and welcoming. I realized that my work isn't just about policy or planning; it's about creating spaces where people like my family can thrive. The interview helped me see how my life experiences and the people around me are intertwined with the kind of change I want to bring about in the world.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Claudia Schultz: A typical week for me is pretty balanced, though it varies depending on my projects and Lily's school schedule. On weekdays, I usually start my day around 7:30 a.m., after getting Lily up and getting her ready for school. I work part-time as a consultant in urban planning, so my days are often spent in meetings, reviewing proposals, or collaborating with local governments and community groups. I try to work from home as much as possible, which gives me more flexibility to be there for Lily when she gets home from school. In the afternoons, we often go to the park or visit the library, and I make sure to cook dinner together as a family. On weekends, I like to spend time with my parents or meet up with friends like Sarah or James. I also try to set aside some time for personal projects, like reading or volunteering at the community garden. It's not always perfect—there are days when I feel stretched thin—but I try to stay present in each moment, because I know how lucky I am to have this life with the people I love.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Claudia Schultz: I work as a part-time urban planning consultant, which allows me to be more present for my family while still engaging in the work I'm passionate about. My days are usually from around 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., though I often start a bit later if I'm working from home and need to get Lily ready for school. I collaborate with local municipalities, community organizations, and sometimes even private developers to help shape policies that support sustainable and inclusive growth. I also do some freelance writing and research on urban equity issues, which I tend to do in the evenings after Lily is asleep. The flexibility of part-time work has been a blessing, especially as a mother, but I also know that I could return to full-time work if the right opportunity came along. What I love most about my job is that it allows me to combine my intellectual interests with my values—making sure that the places we live in are not only functional but also welcoming to everyone, especially those who are often overlooked.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Claudia Schultz: In addition to my work and family life, I have a few other routines that help me stay grounded. Every morning, before getting Lily up, I take a few minutes to meditate or do some light stretching—it's my way of starting the day with intention. I also try to read for at least 20 minutes each night, usually nonfiction about urban development or social justice, which helps me stay informed and inspired. On the weekends, I volunteer at the community garden, which is a way for me to give back and connect with others in a more hands-on way. I also have a weekly phone call with my brother Michael, even if we don't talk often. It's not always easy, but I find that staying in touch, however briefly, helps me appreciate the different paths we've taken and how they've shaped who we are. These small routines, though simple, are important to me—they help me maintain balance and stay connected to the values that guide my life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Claudia Schultz: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my evenings, especially after Lily goes to bed. I've been experimenting with guided meditation apps and journaling to help process the day's events and stay centered. It's something I started doing a few months ago, partly as a way to manage the stress that comes with balancing work, family, and community involvement. I've noticed that it helps me sleep better and approach the next day with more clarity. It's also been a nice way to reflect on my values and how my actions align with them. I think it's important to take time for oneself, even in small ways, and I'm trying to make that a non-negotiable part of my routine now.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Claudia Schultz: Lily's typical weekday during the school year starts early—she's usually up by 7 a.m., and we have a routine of breakfast, brushing teeth, and getting dressed before heading to school. She attends a public elementary school in Evanston, which has a strong focus on arts and environmental education. Her school day runs from 8:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m., and she usually has a snack and recess in between. After school, she comes home and has some time to relax before we have dinner. On most days, she participates in an after-school program at the library where she does creative writing and storytelling. On other days, she joins a small group of friends for soccer or art classes. I love seeing her get excited about learning, and it's heartwarming to know that she's in an environment that encourages curiosity and creativity. It's also a reminder of why I do the work I do—as an urban planner, I want to help create spaces that support the kind of education and community engagement that nurtures kids like Lily.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply intertwined my personal life is with the work I do as an urban planner. Talking about my family, my neighborhood, and my daily routines reminded me of the values that guide my choices—community, equity, and connection. It also made me realize how much my experiences as a mother, wife, and daughter shape the way I approach my work. I see my role as an urban planner not just as a professional responsibility, but as an extension of the life I live every day. Whether it's ensuring that neighborhoods are safe and inclusive or making time for my daughter's education, I'm constantly striving to create spaces—both physical and personal—that support the people I love. The interview helped me see that my work is not separate from who I am; it's a reflection of the life I've built and the values I hold most dear.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Claudia Schultz: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs over the years. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—I loved playing outside, swimming, and later, when I was in college, I took up yoga as a way to manage stress. I still try to keep up with that, though it's harder to find time for it now with work and family. I do my best to eat well, mostly focusing on whole foods, fresh produce, and lean proteins. I've also become more aware of the importance of mental health, especially after having Lily and navigating the challenges of balancing work and motherhood. I've started seeing a therapist occasionally, which has been really helpful in processing some of the pressures I feel. I also make sure to get enough sleep, though it's not always easy with a young child. Overall, I feel lucky to be healthy, and I try to take care of myself in ways that align with the kind of life I want to live—for my family, my work, and my community.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Claudia Schultz: For me, staying healthy is both easier and harder in different ways. On the one hand, living in Evanston gives me access to parks, walking trails, and community events that encourage an active lifestyle. I love taking Lily to the park in the afternoons, and those walks often turn into impromptu exercise sessions for me as well. Plus, being around nature and fresh air helps me feel more balanced, which is something I try to carry into my work and personal life. On the other hand, the demands of being a working mother can make it challenging to prioritize my own health. There are days when I feel like I'm constantly juggling responsibilities, and it's easy to skip a workout or grab a quick, unhealthy meal. I've learned that small, consistent habits matter more than perfection—like making sure I eat a healthy lunch even if I'm busy, or taking a few minutes each day to breathe deeply and reset. I think the key is finding ways to weave health into the rhythm of everyday life, rather than treating it as something separate or optional.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Claudia Schultz: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some chronic lower back pain that started after I lifted Lily during a particularly rough day of play. At first, I thought it was just a minor strain, but it gradually became more persistent, especially after long days of work or helping with household chores. I finally saw a physical therapist a few months ago, and it turned out to be related to poor posture from sitting at my desk for long periods while working from home. The therapist helped me with exercises and stretches, and I've also started using a standing desk to alleviate some of the pressure. It's been a reminder that even small changes can make a big difference in managing pain and staying active. I've also become more mindful of how I move throughout the day, which has helped me feel more in control of my body and my health.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Claudia Schultz: The back pain has definitely had an impact on my daily life, especially when I'm working long hours at my desk or helping Lily with her homework. There were a few weeks where I felt like I was constantly in discomfort, and it made it harder to stay focused on work or be fully present with my family. I had to adjust my routine—like taking more frequent breaks to stretch, using a standing desk, and even incorporating some light physical therapy exercises into my day. It was a bit of a challenge at first, but over time, I've found ways to manage it without letting it take over my life. I've also learned to be more proactive about my health, which is something I want to model for Lily. I don't want her to grow up thinking that pain is just something you have to live with—it's something you can address and improve. In that way, even this challenge has become a part of my journey, teaching me the importance of listening to my body and taking care of myself in ways that support both my work and my family.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Claudia Schultz: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel incredibly grateful for the life I have, and other days I feel the weight of all the responsibilities that come with being a mother, a professional, and a community member. There have been moments of deep fulfillment, like when I helped draft a proposal for a new community center that will provide safe spaces for children and families in Evanston. That felt like a real step forward in the work I care about. But there have also been times when I've felt overwhelmed, especially when balancing work deadlines with Lily's needs or when I'm trying to stay on top of my health while managing everything else. I've learned to be more compassionate with myself, though, and to recognize that it's okay to have off days. I've also found comfort in the small, everyday moments—like watching Lily laugh while we're in the park, or sharing a quiet evening with Daniel. Those are the things that remind me why I do what I do, and they help me keep going even when things feel heavy.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines are intertwined with the rest of my life. Discussing my recent mindfulness practices, the challenges of staying healthy as a working mother, and my chronic back pain reminded me of how important it is to take care of myself—not just for my own well-being, but for the people I love. It also made me realize how small changes, like incorporating meditation or using a standing desk, can have a big impact on my overall balance and ability to show up for my family and work. These reflections have helped me see that health isn't just about physical fitness; it's about mental resilience, self-awareness, and the choices I make every day to live in alignment with my values.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Claudia Schultz: I think I've experienced moments of anxiety, especially during the busier times when work and family responsibilities felt overwhelming. There were days when I worried I wasn't doing enough for Lily or that I wasn't making a meaningful impact in my work. I remember one particularly stressful period when I was juggling a major project at work, helping Lily with a school presentation, and also dealing with the ongoing back pain. It felt like everything was pulling me in different directions, and I wasn't sure how to keep up. I started seeing a therapist a few months ago, and that's been really helpful. Talking through those feelings has allowed me to process them in a healthier way, and I've learned to recognize when I need to slow down or ask for help. I don't think I'd label it as clinical anxiety, but I do believe that everyone has moments of stress and self-doubt, and it's important to address them before they become heavier to carry. I've come to see those feelings not as failures, but as signals that I need to take a step back and realign with what truly matters to me.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Claudia Schultz: For my family, it's been a year of navigating the same challenges I've faced, but also of finding strength in our shared experiences. Daniel has been incredibly supportive, though I know he's also felt the pressure of balancing his work with being there for Lily. He's taken on more of the household responsibilities, especially when I've been dealing with the back pain, and I'm so grateful for his patience and understanding. Lily, on the other hand, has been a constant source of joy and resilience. She's growing up in a world that feels both exciting and uncertain, and I see her starting to understand the complexities of the world around her. She asks questions about fairness, about why some people have more than others, and it reminds me of why my work matters. I think she's picking up on the values I try to live by, and that gives me hope for the future. We've had our rough moments, but overall, I feel like we're holding on to each other through it all, and that's what keeps us going.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Claudia Schultz: I was raised Catholic, and for a long time, I held on to those beliefs, especially during my childhood. But as I grew older and started questioning more about the world, I found that my faith didn't quite align with the way I saw things. I began to see religion more as a personal journey rather than something I needed to follow strictly. Now, I would say I'm more spiritual than religious—I believe in the importance of community, connection, and living with intention, but I don't tie those values to a specific faith. I still respect the role religion plays in people's lives, and I think it can be a source of comfort and meaning for many. For me, it's more about the values I carry with me every day, like kindness, equity, and the belief that we all deserve to live in a world that supports and uplifts everyone. I think that's what matters most, whether or not you label it as spiritual or religious.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Claudia Schultz: I use social media pretty selectively, mostly to stay connected with friends and colleagues in my field. I have a Facebook account where I keep in touch with my parents, my brother, and some old friends from college. I also follow a few urban planning and social justice pages that share interesting research or community stories—I find it helpful to stay informed about the issues that matter to me. I'm not really on Instagram or Twitter, though I've considered it sometimes. I think social media can be a powerful tool for connection and advocacy, but I also know how easy it is to get caught up in the noise or feel overwhelmed by the constant stream of information. For me, it's more about quality than quantity. I try to use it in a way that aligns with my values—supporting causes I care about, sharing resources that might help others, and staying in touch with the people who matter most. It's not a big part of my life, but when I do use it, I try to be intentional about how I engage with the world online.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Claudia Schultz: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I think I've always leaned more on my immediate circle—my family, my close friends, and my colleagues in the urban planning field. When I've been struggling, whether it was with work, health, or just the general chaos of life, it's been the people I know in person who have offered the most meaningful support. That said, I do think social media can be a double-edged sword. I've seen friends find community and encouragement online, especially around issues like mental health or parenting, and I respect that. For me, though, I prefer face-to-face connections or phone calls where I can really hear someone's voice and feel their presence. I guess I'm more of a traditionalist in that sense. Still, I'm not closed off to the idea—I just haven't found the need for it in the way some people do.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and emotional well-being are deeply connected to the rest of my life. Discussing my chronic back pain and the challenges of managing it as a working mother reminded me of how physical health can impact every aspect of daily living, from my ability to focus at work to being fully present with Lily. It also made me think about the emotional toll of balancing so many responsibilities and how it's okay to feel overwhelmed at times. Talking about my anxiety and the moments when I felt like I wasn't doing enough for my family or my work helped me realize how important it is to be kind to myself and to seek support when needed. I've come to see these struggles not as weaknesses, but as part of the journey—reminders that I need to take care of myself so I can continue showing up for the people and causes I care about. It's comforting to know that I'm not alone in these feelings, and that even small steps, like seeing a therapist or adjusting my routine, can make a meaningful difference in how I feel and function every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Claudia Schultz: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels fluctuate, but I've been more intentional about how I manage it. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of everything—work, family, and my own health—without really taking a breath. But I've started to build in more moments of reflection and self-compassion. I've been journaling more, especially in the evenings, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions. I've also found that talking through my feelings with Daniel or my close friends has been incredibly grounding. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but I've learned that asking for support isn't a weakness—it's a strength. I've also started setting clearer boundaries around my work and personal time, which has helped me feel more in control. It's not always perfect, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and to recognize that it's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes. I think the key has been finding small, consistent ways to care for my emotional well-being, even when life feels complicated.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Claudia Schultz: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to housing, childcare, and groceries. We live in a modest home in Evanston, and while the mortgage is manageable, it's still a significant portion of our budget. Lily's childcare costs are another major expense—since we both work part-time, we use a combination of a local daycare and after-school programs, which adds up. Groceries are also a regular expense, especially since I try to prioritize healthy, organic foods whenever possible. We also have some recurring bills like internet, utilities, and car insurance. To make ends meet, I've been careful with our spending, and we've made a conscious effort to limit unnecessary purchases. Daniel and I also both have part-time jobs, which helps, but it's not always easy to balance work and family without feeling stretched thin. I think the biggest challenge is ensuring that we're saving for the future while still being able to cover our day-to-day needs. It's a constant balancing act, but we're managing, and I'm grateful for the stability we have.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Claudia Schultz: Last month, our household spent roughly around $5,500, which is about what we usually spend each month. The breakdown is pretty consistent—housing is the largest chunk, around $2,200 for the mortgage, and then about $1,200 on childcare, which includes both the daycare and the after-school programs Lily attends. Groceries come in at around $800, and we also have about $500 for utilities, internet, and car insurance. We try to be mindful of our spending, so we don't go overboard on entertainment or dining out, though we do treat ourselves to a family meal out once in a while. I think the key for us is that we're both working part-time, which gives us some flexibility, but also means we have to be careful with our budget. We also set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just a few hundred dollars. It's not always easy, but we've found a rhythm that works for us, and I feel lucky that we're able to manage without too much stress.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Claudia Schultz: We own our home, though it was a decision we made after a lot of careful consideration. We bought it a few years ago when the market was still relatively stable, and it's been a good investment so far. It's a three-bedroom house on Lakeview Drive, which is exactly where I grew up, and that connection to my roots has been meaningful for me. Owning a home has given us a sense of stability, especially with Lily's future in mind. We're not in a rush to move, and I think we're both happy with the decision. It's not without its challenges—maintaining a home, especially with a young child, can be time-consuming—but it's something we've come to appreciate. I think it's also a reflection of the values we hold—building a life that's secure, rooted, and built on the foundation of community, which is something I carry into both my personal and professional life.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Claudia Schultz: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, especially with the seasons and Lily's school calendar. In the winter months, our heating bill tends to spike, and we also spend a bit more on groceries because we're cooking more at home and trying to keep the kids warm. During the summer, we use less electricity for heating, but we do spend more on outdoor activities, like buying sunscreen, swim gear, and sometimes even a family trip to a nearby lake or park. Holidays also bring some fluctuations—around Christmas, we tend to spend a bit more on gifts and decorations, and we usually have a bigger grocery bill for holiday meals. When school starts in the fall, the childcare costs stay pretty consistent, but we do have some extra expenses for back-to-school supplies and activities. On the other hand, during the summer when Lily is out of school, we sometimes save a little by not needing as much childcare, but we also spend more on enrichment programs or camps. Overall, it's been a balancing act, but we've learned to plan ahead and adjust our spending throughout the year to stay on track.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and emotional well-being are intertwined with the challenges I face in daily life. Discussing my health struggles, the emotional toll of balancing work and family, and the support I receive from my loved ones reminded me of how important it is to lean on the people I trust. It also made me think about how my spiritual beliefs have evolved over time—from being raised Catholic to finding meaning in values like community, equity, and connection. I realized that while I may not follow a strict religious path, the principles I live by are just as meaningful in shaping who I am. These reflections helped me see that my journey is not just about personal growth, but also about the relationships and values that anchor me, even when life feels overwhelming.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Claudia Schultz: I do save, though it's more of a conscious, small-scale effort rather than something I do automatically. We have a savings account that we contribute to each month, even if it's just a few hundred dollars. It's not a huge amount, but it gives us a sense of security, especially for unexpected expenses or for Lily's future. I think the key for us has been consistency—setting aside a little bit each month, even when it feels tight, has helped us build a cushion over time. We also have some emergency funds tucked away in a separate account, which we've been able to use for things like car repairs or medical costs. I know not everyone has that luxury, and I'm grateful for the stability we have. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared and making choices that align with our values—like investing in our daughter's education or supporting our community. I think saving, for us, is less about wealth and more about peace of mind, knowing that we're doing what we can to build a secure and meaningful life.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Claudia Schultz: In the last year, I've been saving more intentionally for both short-term and long-term goals. We have an emergency fund that we've been building up, which has been really important, especially with Lily's healthcare needs and the ongoing costs of maintaining our home. I also started saving for her future education, even if it's just a small amount each month. It's something I want to model for her—showing her that planning ahead and investing in the future, even in small ways, can make a difference. I also set aside a little money each month for personal development, like books or courses related to urban planning or social justice. It's not about having a lot, but about making choices that reflect our values and preparing for the unknown. I think that's what saving means to me now—it's about creating a sense of stability and possibility, not just for my family, but for the kind of world I want to help build.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Claudia Schultz: My occupation is a part-time urban planning consultant, and it's a role that brings together everything I care about—community, equity, and creating spaces that support people's lives. In this work, I collaborate with local governments, community organizations, and sometimes private developers to help shape policies and projects that promote sustainable and inclusive growth. The most important activities in my job involve listening to residents, especially those who are often overlooked, and translating their needs into actionable plans. I spend a lot of time conducting research, analyzing data, and attending public meetings where people share their stories and concerns. One of the most rewarding parts of my work is seeing a proposal come to life, like the community center I helped draft last year, which now provides a safe and welcoming space for families in Evanston. It's not always easy—there are political challenges, budget constraints, and competing interests—but what keeps me going is the belief that the work we do, even in small ways, can make a real difference in people's lives. I think of it as an extension of the values I was raised with and the life I'm building with my family. It's not just about planning cities; it's about planning for people, and that's what gives my work its meaning.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Claudia Schultz: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours per week, depending on the project I'm involved in and how much time I need to be available for Lily's schedule. There are weeks when I'm fully immersed in a proposal or a community meeting, and those days can feel more intense, but I try to keep my workload balanced so I can be present for my family. I've found that part-time work gives me the flexibility I need to manage both my professional and personal responsibilities without feeling stretched too thin. It's not always easy to juggle everything, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most—whether that's being there for Lily, supporting my community, or making sure my work aligns with my values. I think the key is knowing my limits and being willing to say no when necessary, which has been something I've had to practice over the years.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Claudia Schultz: I actually did have another part-time role a few years ago, though I've since shifted my focus entirely to urban planning. For a while, I worked evenings and weekends as a freelance writer, mostly contributing to local publications and community newsletters. It was a way to stay connected to the issues I cared about while also earning some extra income. I wrote about everything from education reform to environmental sustainability, and it was rewarding to see my words reach people in the community. However, as my work in urban planning grew more demanding and as Lily came into our lives, I realized I needed to be more present for my family. So I gradually phased out the writing gig, though I still do some occasional freelance projects when my schedule allows. It's been a good reminder that flexibility is key, and that sometimes you have to let go of one path to make room for another that aligns more closely with your values and priorities.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my emotional well-being and financial stability are deeply connected to the daily challenges I face as a mother, urban planner, and community member. Discussing my stress levels, coping strategies, and how I manage my household budget reminded me of the delicate balance I strive to maintain in my life. It also made me think about how important it is to be intentional with both my time and resources, especially when raising a child and working in a field that values equity and inclusion. I've come to realize that managing stress isn't just about finding time for self-care—it's about recognizing that my emotional health directly impacts my ability to show up for my family and my work. At the same time, talking about our monthly expenses and savings reminded me of the responsibility I have to provide for Lily's future while staying true to my values. It's a constant negotiation between what I need and what I want, but I'm learning to be more compassionate with myself in the process. These reflections have helped me see that my journey is not just about personal growth, but also about creating a life that supports both my well-being and the well-being of those I love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Claudia Schultz: In total, our household made roughly around $6,500 in the past month. That includes my part-time consulting work, Daniel's income from his software development job, and some freelance writing I did on the side. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and give us some flexibility. I think what's most important to me is that we're not just surviving—we're thriving in the way that matters to us. We're able to provide for Lily, support our community, and still have time for the things that bring us joy, like weekend walks in the park or quiet evenings at home. It's not always easy, but I feel lucky that we've found a balance that works for our family.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Claudia Schultz: I've been working as a part-time urban planning consultant for about four years now, though my journey in this field has been longer than that. I started out as a full-time employee with a local municipality, but after having Lily, I transitioned to part-time work to be more present for her. The benefits of my current job are pretty standard for part-time roles—health insurance is the most important one, as it covers both Daniel and me, and it includes some mental health services, which I've found really helpful. We also get a few weeks of paid time off each year, which is something I try to use for family vacations or to recharge. Sick time is more limited, but I've learned to be proactive about taking care of myself so I don't burn out. One of the things I appreciate most about my job is the flexibility—it allows me to work from home most of the time, which is a huge help with balancing work and family. I also get to collaborate with people who are passionate about creating better communities, which makes the work feel meaningful even on the days when it's challenging.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Claudia Schultz: My relationships at work are generally positive and collaborative. I work with a variety of people—local government officials, community organizers, and sometimes even residents who are directly impacted by the projects we're working on. My manager, who I'll call Rachel, is someone I really respect. She's been in the field for over a decade and has a deep understanding of both the technical and human sides of urban planning. She's supportive of my work-life balance, which is something I really appreciate, especially as a mother. We have a good rapport, and she's always willing to listen and offer guidance when I need it. As for my coworkers, I work with a small team of consultants, and we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We often collaborate on projects, and I value the way we challenge each other's ideas while also supporting one another's growth. I think the key to our good relationships is that we all share a common goal—making sure that the communities we work with are not just developed, but truly inclusive and sustainable. It's not always easy, and there are moments when we disagree or face difficult challenges, but I feel like I'm part of a team that cares about the work we do and the people we serve.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Claudia Schultz: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is one of the things I value most about my job. Since I work as a consultant, I don't have a set 9-to-5 routine like I did when I was full-time. Most of my projects are structured around deadlines or community meetings, so I can often plan my days around Lily's school schedule or personal commitments. That said, there are times when I have to be more rigid, especially when I'm in the middle of a major project or preparing for a public hearing. I try to communicate clearly with my clients and colleagues so they know when I'm available and when I might need to adjust my hours. Flexibility is a double-edged sword—it gives me the freedom to be present for my family, but it also requires me to be disciplined in managing my time. I've learned to set boundaries, like designating specific hours for work and making sure I take breaks to recharge. It's not perfect, but it's a balance that works for me and allows me to stay engaged in the work I love without sacrificing the things that matter most.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Claudia Schultz: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation, though I know it's not without its challenges. We're not wealthy by any means, but we're stable enough to cover our needs and even have some room for small indulgences or savings. I think what matters most to me is that we're not living paycheck to paycheck, and that we're able to provide Lily with the opportunities and experiences that will help her grow into a thoughtful, compassionate person. There are days when I worry about the future—about whether we'll be able to afford college for her, or if we'll have to make difficult choices if something unexpected comes up. But I also know that we've built a life that's rooted in values, and that gives me a sense of security I can't put a price on. I'm not sure if I'd call it financial freedom, but I do feel like we're on a path that allows us to live with purpose, and that's something I'm grateful for.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial stability and emotional well-being are intertwined with the daily rhythms of my life as a mother, urban planner, and community member. Discussing how our bills fluctuate with the seasons and Lily's school calendar reminded me of the importance of planning and adaptability in managing our household. It also made me think about how my part-time work and savings habits contribute to a sense of security, even if we're not living in luxury. Talking about my emotional coping strategies and how I manage stress highlighted the need to be intentional with both my time and resources, especially when raising a child and working in a field that values equity and inclusion. I've come to realize that financial stability isn't just about numbers—it's about creating a life that supports both my well-being and the well-being of those I love.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Claudia Schultz: Yes, my mother worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up, though she eventually chose to step back from full-time work to focus on our family and community involvement. She worked as a teacher in the Evanston public school system for several years before I was born, and even after I was born, she continued teaching part-time for a while. I remember her being very dedicated to her students and to the community, and I think that's where I got my own passion for education and public service. However, as I grew older, she decided to take a break from teaching to be more present for our family and to volunteer in other ways, like with the food bank and the nonprofit that supports education for underprivileged children. I always admired her for making that choice, and it showed me that there are many ways to contribute to society—whether through paid work, volunteering, or raising children with values that matter. It's something I think about often, especially as I balance my own career and family life.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Claudia Schultz: My mother worked as a teacher in the Evanston public school system, and her most important activities revolved around creating a supportive and inclusive learning environment for her students. She was known for her patience, creativity, and deep commitment to education. I remember her spending long hours grading papers, planning lessons, and staying after school to help students who were struggling. What stood out to me most was how she treated every child with respect and believed in their potential, even when others didn't. She also made it a point to stay involved in the community—whether it was organizing parent-teacher meetings, volunteering at school events, or mentoring new teachers. Her work wasn't just about academics; it was about shaping young minds and instilling values like empathy and curiosity. Even after she stepped back from full-time teaching, she continued to support education through her volunteer work, which is something I deeply admire. I think her example is what inspired me to pursue a career in public service, where I can make a difference in people's lives in a similar way, even if the setting is different.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Claudia Schultz: My mother worked for the Evanston public school system, which is a local government entity that oversees education in our area. It's not a for-profit business, but rather a public institution that serves the community by providing education to children from diverse backgrounds. Her role as a teacher involved not only teaching subjects like math and literature, but also fostering a sense of belonging and curiosity in her students. She made sure that every child felt seen and heard, and she often stayed late to help those who needed extra support. She didn't make a lot of money compared to other professions, but she always said that the rewards of seeing her students grow and succeed were more valuable than any salary. I remember her talking about the challenges of working in a public school—like limited resources and large class sizes—but she never lost her passion for teaching. She believed that education was the foundation of a just society, and that belief shaped the way she approached her work every day. I think that's why I was drawn to public policy and urban planning—because I wanted to be part of something that had a similar impact, even if the setting was different.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Claudia Schultz: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still living in Evanston, still working in urban planning, and still being present for Lily as she grows into her own person. I hope she's curious, kind, and passionate about making the world a better place, just like I am. I also hope that my work has made a tangible difference in our community—whether it's through a new park, a safer neighborhood, or more equitable housing policies. I don't know if I'll ever be wealthy, but I hope I'm content with the life we've built, one that values connection, purpose, and the little things that make life meaningful. I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding ways to give back. And most of all, I hope I'm still surrounded by the people I love—Daniel, Lily, my parents, and the friends who have been there for me through it all. That's what I truly hope for.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Claudia Schultz: What I value the most in my life is connection—both to the people I love and to the communities I get to work with. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of daily life, but what keeps me grounded is the sense of belonging I feel with my family, my friends, and the people I serve through my work. I value the moments when I'm sitting at the kitchen table with Lily, listening to her talk about her day, or when I'm walking through the neighborhood with Daniel, just enjoying the quiet. I also value the work I do because it allows me to contribute to something bigger than myself, to help shape spaces where people can thrive. But more than anything, I value the relationships that anchor me—my parents, my husband, my daughter, and the people who have supported me along the way. They are the foundation of who I am, and I'm grateful for every one of them.

It also made me think about how my part-time job in urban planning provides not just financial security, but also flexibility and purpose. The conversations about my workplace, relationships with my manager and coworkers, and the flexibility of my schedule highlighted how much I value a job that supports both my professional goals and my family life. These reflections helped me see that my financial situation is not just about numbers—it's about creating a life that allows me to be present for the people I love while still contributing to the communities I care about.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective journey for me. It reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the people I love, the values I hold dear, and the choices I've made along the way. From my childhood in Evanston, where I was raised in a supportive and intellectually stimulating environment, to the pivotal internship that shifted my career path from law to public policy, each step has led me to where I am today. It wasn't just about making a decision—it was about aligning my values with my work, and I'm grateful for the guidance I received along the way. Now, as a mother and a part-time urban planner, I feel a deep sense of purpose, knowing that I'm contributing to my community in a way that matters to me. The interview process helped me see how interconnected my past experiences, relationships, and choices have been in defining who I am now. It's a reminder that life is not just a series of events, but a tapestry woven from the people, moments, and values that shape us. I'm grateful for this journey and for the life I've built—one that is rooted in connection, purpose, and the belief that we can all make a difference, no matter how small our actions may seem.
